description: From Middle English poynaunt, poynant, borrowed from Anglo-Norman puignant, poynaunt etc., present participle of poindre (“to prick”), from Latin pungō (“prick”). Doublet of pungent.

adjectives.description: poignant (comparative more poignant, superlative most poignant)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, of a weapon, etc.) Sharp-pointed; keen.

examples: A poignant reply will garner more credence than hours of blown smoke.

entries.meaning: Evoking strong mental sensation, to the point of distress; emotionally moving.
examples: Flipping through his high school yearbook evoked many a poignant memory of yesteryear.

entries.meaning: (figuratively, of a smell, taste) Piquant, pungent.
(figuratively, of a look, word) Incisive; penetrating; piercing.
examples: His comments were poignant and witty.

entries.meaning: (chiefly Britain, dated) Inducing sharp physical pain.
